title: Ticket #38: Unhelpful hold reason when periodic expression is UNDEFINED
description:
(Copied from Drupal 1364 (backup) 1364 (public).)

If a job has a periodic expression, but it evaluates to UNDEFINED, the resulting job is put on hold. The hold reason is not helpful. The hold reason is 

HoldReason = "The UNKNOWN (never set) PeriodicRemove expression '' evaluated to UNDEFINED"

This is particularly confusing, since it suggests that the PeriodicRemove expression was never set, when indeed it was. It also has a blank where it looks like the expression should be placed.

The expected output might look something like: 

HoldReason = "The PeriodicRemove expression 'DoesNotExist > 0' evaluated to UNDEFINED"

To reproduce, try this submit file on a reasonably supported Linux: 

universe=vanilla
executable=/bin/date
log=eraseme.log
periodic_remove = DoesNotExist > 0
queue

Wait a few moments and the job should go on hold. The hold reason will be visible via `condor_q -format '%s\n' HoldReason` or in the eraseme.log userlog.
remarks:
Put this into the master.

2010-Jul-16 17:04:36 by mccardel:
The problem was that the function AnalyzeSinglePeriodicPolicy in condor_c++_util/user_job_policy.cpp couldn't tell the difference between when an attribute was undefined and when something inside the expression was undefined. This function was called from AnalyzePolicy() in the same file, which in turn was called from PeriodicExprEval() in condor_schedd.v6/schedd.cpp.

The call to ASPP would generate a return value of UNDEFINED_EVAL, and this would propagate up to PeriodicExprEval(). Following this, the UserPolicy is checked again; this time to see what the firing reason was. Originally, FiringReason() would see that the variable m_firing_source hadn't been set yet, and would set part of the error string to be "UNKNOWN (never set)", because the type of thing that tripped the firing code was never set. It should've been set in ASPP, but that quit before it could set the firing source.

However, the code in ASPP now differentiates between when an attribute is undefined and when its expression is undefined. This was done by adding an if-block that looked up the attrname in the classad, and made sure it wasn't null. If it isn't null, then we know that we can set m_firing_source to be a job attribute and that the expression is undefined.

Thus, the error message is now the following: 

  The job attribute PeriodicRemove expression 'DoesNotExist > 0' evaluated to UNDEFINED
